VOL. XXXII, No. 57

JAYS PLACE FOURTH
IN M.A.S. C. MEET
Hopkins Upsets Predictions to
Score Eighteen Points
SIX RECORDS BROKEN
Gwinn and SchiebelPress Leaders to New Distance Marks
Blue Jay trackmen showed unlooked-for strength and were able
to place fourth in the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic
Association Championships at Haverford on Friday and Saturday of
last week, amassing a total of 18
points. New York University retained its title by scoring 602
points, with Haverford second with
41 points and Swarthmore third
with 25 points.
Gwinn Runs Mile

1

Hopkins was not able to garner
any first places, but was a close
second in three events—the mile and
two-mile runs and the broad jump.
In the one-mile run Gwinn was
picked to win by all of the experts,
but his chief opponent was declared
to be McMillan, of Union College.
The race started off at a good pace,
and after the first two laps Gwinn,
McMillan, and Getz, from Alfred
College, were bunched in the van.
At the beginning of the final lap
Alfred's entry began to sprint and
opened up a great lead on the other
two. Midway down the backstretch
Gwinn opened up and easily passed
McMillan, but he had allowed Getz
to get too much of a lead on him and
never was able to overhaul the fleet
New York runner. The last twenty
yards of the race were stirring, with
Gwinn coming on like an express
train and the yellow-jerseyed runner
in the lead just able to finish the
race, and establish a new Middle
States record for the mile of 4
minutes 2375 seconds, lowering the
old mark by 33
/
5 seconds.
New Record in Two-Mile Run

The second great distance performance of the day was turned in
by Schiebel, of the Jays, in the twomile. After the first two laps were
over, there were two distinctly different groups of runners. In the
lead was Totten of Union College,
Shirk of Dickinson, and Schiebel of
Hopkins.
This trio thundered
through the race, almost lapping the
remainder of the field. Just before
the beginning of the last lap, Totten
and Schiebel began to sprint, leaving
little Shirk far in the rear. Coming
around the last turn, the Union runner was able to gain a few yards and
he held this advantage through to
the finish, with Schiebel unable to
quite pick up the distance. Both
ran within the record time and
established a new mark of 9 minutes
4075 seconds. From out of nowhere Gwinn appeared and passed
Shirk in the last few strides for a
third place.
Other Points Scored

\riven garnered second place in
the broad jump, a wonderful showing considering the twisted muscles
in his legs. Berger's fourth in the
discus and W. Scheidt's fifth place
in the pole vault completed the scoring for the Jays.
This was the sixteenth annual
meet for the Middle States Champioaships and probably the fastest
one, six out of fourteen records
being equaled or broken.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 22, 1928

STRADER TO HEAD
VARSITY CLUB IN'29
Don.Stroder has been elected President of the Varsity
Club for next year, according
to a recent announcement.
Herman Scheibel was selected
for vice-presidency. The election is an annual occurrence
and was held last Thursday.
The meeting was the last one
of the year.
At the meeting, also, arrangements were made to
make elaborate preparations
for next year's entertainment
of out-of-town athletic teams.
Plans were made to more elaboratelv entertain high school
students who are prospective
athletes.

MAJOR McKINNEY
TO HEAD R. 0. T. C.
Mayor C. F. McKinney will
succeed Major G. Hoisington
to the post of supervisor of
the Hopkins branch of the R.
0. T. C. Major McKinney
has been selected from the
general staff in Washington.
Major Hoisington, who has
been stationed at Hopkins for
four years, will be transferred
to Fort Benning, Georgia. He
has been exceptionally successful during his stay here,
his unit having been on the
distinguished list three years.
The remainder of the staff will
remain intact.

Last year just about this time a scrappy Scarlet lacrosse twelve gave
the stick world the biggest surprise of the season when it took a toosure Syracuse twelve into camp and ruined the latters' hope for intercollegiate stick laurels. Only last Wednesday the game New Brunswick stickmen handed lacrosse fans in general and Army in particular
the most upsetting jolt of the present season when Harry Wilson and
his teammates bowed to the Rutgers Scarlet by a 8-to-3 defeat.
. * * * * *
With the defeat of Army by Rutgers, only two of the many Olympic
contenders remain undefeated—Maryland and Mt. Washington. The
Olympic Committee, however, has assured stick fans that nothing has
been definitely decided, and nothing will be until the season is finished.
Should Hopkins defeat Maryland Saturday, Mt. Washington would
remain the only undefeated team in the country. But the Hillmen have
not played what are conceded to be three of the strongest teams in the
running—Army, Navy and Maryland. Their outstanding victory over
an Olympic contender, and almost their only one, is their victory over
Syracuse.
• * * * *
The much-defeated Harvard twelve was certainly made to feel the
results of the Army defeat Wednesday. Journeying to West Point
last Saturday, Wilson and Draper gave the Crimson twelve almost as
warm a reception as any received on the ill-fated Southern tour of the
Harvard stickmen when Doug. Turnbull and Fenny Baker went on
their scoring jag to chalk up a record score for the benefit of any
Olympic judges who might be present.
* * * * *
Mt. Washington this year is conceded to be the strongest twelve in
the country, and unless some quite unforeseen upset like the Army
defeat occurs, the Hillmen are almost sure of journeying to Amsterdam.
On May 30 the Mt. 'Washington stickmen will meet the toughtest team
on the schedule—the L'Hirondelle twelve—and anything might happen.
Both the Swallows and the Hillmen,,will go into the scrap with everything they've got. And they both have quite a lot.
* * * * *
The Swallows didn't give promise of much of a team at the beginning
of the season. They dropped their first two games—one to Maryland
at the end of March and their second to the fighting Johnnies at the
beginning of April. But since then their stock has gone up considerably, especially after the decisive 9-to-5 victory over the Crescents.
Any Mt. Washington-L'Hirondelle game, however, will furnish all the
fight and thrills of a EIopkins-Maryland scrap, no matter what the
caliber of the teams.

LITTLE THEATRE ORCHESTRA
Mats., 35c; Eves., 50c.

Never Gets
a "Bite" From
This Tobacco
Jasper, Tenn.
March 23, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
I have always wanted to smoke a
pipe. After several attempts I gave
my "taste" up, for with each trial I
got a blistered tongue.
One evening, when looking over a
certain outdoor magazine, I read that
a certain fisherman could catch more
fish when using "Edgeworth," so I
decided I would try "his" tobacco—
for I am no poor fisherman!
The next day I tried to secure Edgeworth. The local country storekeeper
did not have it, so I sent by a friend to
the city for my first Edgeworth. Two
things have happened: I still smoke
Edgeworth, and the local storekeeper
always has a supply.
I catch fish and never get "a bite"
from Edgeworth!
Yours for keeps,
H. V. Massey

THE JOHN HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 22, 1928

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
Recalling his own college days as
being rather prankish and happygo-lucky, Dean Clark, of the University of Illinois, whom we picture
as a very exceptional and an unusually truthful faculty member, has
sufficient courage in his convictions
to state that "students of today
stand out as the most capable and
broadminded group of scholars in
the history of the country. Furthermore, modern colleges and universities are realizing a greater and
finer thing in college education than
they have ever approached before."
Unusually enough Dean Clark further ascribes one cause of the improved and more mature student as
being due to college activities which
as he says "have brought about a
radical change in the importance of
a college education."

THE JOHN HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 22, 1928

4

HALL HEARINGS
If statistics were taken to ascertain the number of students who always increase the size of their vacations, it is probable that the number
would be considerable. This was
the case in the Hall immediately
after the Easter furlough. Hardly
half the residents were present in
the dining room until the Monday
following vacation. The graduate
students, especially, enjoyed this, as
the usual amount of shoving and
pushing to get to the table first was
lacking.
*

*

*

The Scorpion Club of B entry has
been rather inactive of late. This is
an organization consisting of certain
members of B entry and an honorary member from F who was elected
to the club for his valuable and enlightening speeches on members of
the opposite sex. The club was in
the habit of meeting semi-monthly
(or any other time). The original
purpose of the club was to hold full
sessions weekly but when MacK. began to impart his information, the
meetings were in the form of lectures. Probably when he has exhausted his vast store of knowledge
on the subject, the club will revert
to the old system.
*

*

*

*

*

Each noon, crowds of students
can be seen in the Hall office reserving rooms for next year. They certainly are an optimistic lot.
*

*

*

The entry "B" boys have lost
their reputation of being a rough,
noisy and thoroughly disreputable
entry to the boys of "C" entry. The
entry "C" boys have been working
hard for this reputation for the past
several months and deserve it. At
last they have won it from "B,"
their rival entry for this distinction.
A recent party in "C" was the deciding factor. The entry "B" boys
themselves agreed that this party.
was equivalent to two of their best
parties. For three years "B" entry
was avoided by graduate students.
However, two graduate students
moved from "C" this year and one
last year.

leading Cigarettes, Princess Paul Chavchavadze

OLD GOLD

"I was much intrigued by the invitation to make
a blindfold test of your leading brands of American cigarettes, to see how they compared with
each other and with those I had smoked abroad.
Could one really taste the difference? I wondered.
"But when I was handed these cigarettes, one by
one, I realized at once that there was a difference
and that the test was conclusive. One cigarette
was so much more appealing, so much more
delicate in flavor. Oh, and so much smoother!
"When the test was over and I was told that the
cigarette of my choice was OLD GOLD I understood
at once why this cigarette is so popular among
my American friends."

To calculate the number of tons
of mud tracked into the rooms of
Alumni Memorial Hall during the
rainfall last Friday would be an interesting problem for a graduate
student interested in transportation
methods in distribution of matter.
Friday the courtyard was entirely
submerged.

Joe Dorm attended a work-out of
the Alumni Memorial Hall Boxing
Organization, which exists for the
purpose of promoting the manly art
of self-defense. Joe suffered a set
of sore muscles after a severe battle
with his shadow.

On the Sunday morning of banquet season, at about 2 A. M., thirty
freshmen came to the Hall in quest
of a certain sophomore. They
knocked on his door and he failed
to reply. Unfortunately for him he
lived on the first floor. The frosh
then went to the back of the Hall
and, on finding the window locked,
broke one of them and walked in.
Where they got in they discovered
that his roommate, another soph,
had locked himself in the closet.
They immediately proceeded to take
down the closet door and haul out
the poor frightened little sophomore.
In getting out of the room they
pushed four panels out of two doors
and pulled the knobs off said portals.
Needless to say the room was quite
a wreck.

Hullabaloo To Make
Appearance June 6
"The printing of the Hullabaloo
was started today and is expected
to be completed by June 6," Leonard Dalsemer, business manager,
announced last Friday. This is the
usual time for the publication of the
year book. Notices will be sent to
all students when the Hullabaloo
arrives and those who are out of
town at the time will receive their
year books next fall. This issue is
about 460 pages in length. The
color scheme has been changed from
the usual black.
INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
(Continued From Page 3, Column 1)

An ugly men's contest which is at
present underway at the University
of Cincinnati appears to be the latest in collegiate eccentricities, fads,
foibles, or what not. This novelty,
it is reported, has been adopted in
opposition to "nauseating" beauty
contests which are becoming increasingly popular even in college
today. Six candidates are entered
to date. Campaign speeches will be
made and after the voting "the ugliest man in the university" will be
given a silver loving cup at-the Annual Boat Ride.

BRITISH STUDENTS WILL STUDY AT
UNIVERSITY AS COMMONWEALTH FELLOWS
Hugh Graham Soulsby and
George E. Taylor, students of English universities, will come to Johns
Hopkins this year as holders of
Commonwealth fund fellowships,
according to a recent announcement.
Soulsby is a graduate of Durham
University, while Taylor is a student at Birmingham University.
The Durham graduate will study
Anglo-American relations in the
nineteenth century with reference to
the freedom of the seas and rights
of neutral powers in time of war.
Taylor will study the expansion of
the United States from the SpanishAmerican War to the World War.

The fellowships were established
in 1925 by the Commonwealth fund
of New York. They are awarded
annually and give the selected graduates of British and Colonial universities two years of study in
American universities and a summer
of travel in this country.

"The reaction of the undergraduate student body to the newly proposed cage has been favorable,"
said Dr. Ray Van Orman. The
demonstration during Thursday's
assembly at which "Father Bill"
Schmeisser explained the project
and urged support has been very encouraging. By last Friday approximately three thousand dollars had

Waldo Hambleton will take over
the coaching of the Hopkins track
and field team. He has been working with Ridgely Edwards throughout the past year to give him experience and get him acquainted with
Hopkins methods and men. He assisted Edwards not because a larger
staff is needed but. because of the
experience. He alone will coach the
team next year. Hambleton is an
old Hopkins man himself. He was
a weight man in his undergraduate
days, was on the swimming team,
and took part in the Musical Club.
Hambleton is now teaching over at
Poly.
Edwards To Leave

Ridgely Edwards is going to
Louisiana State University where
he wlil be assistant professor in
chemistry. It is not known whether
he will coach there or not. Edwards
leaves Hopkins with an enviable
record as a coach. "He has been
the best track coach since I have
been here," said Van Orman. "He
has always had the support of his
men. He has accomplished more
and turned out more stars from
raw material than any other coach
I know of." The past season during which the track team won every
meet scheduled has been Edwards'
most successful year. The team
was well balanced and strong.

VOL. XXXII, No. 57

JAYS PLACE FOURTH
IN M.A.S. C. MEET
Hopkins Upsets Predictions to
Score Eighteen Points
SIX RECORDS BROKEN
Gwinn and SchiebelPress Leaders to New Distance Marks
Blue Jay trackmen showed unlooked-for strength and were able
to place fourth in the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic
Association Championships at Haverford on Friday and Saturday of
last week, amassing a total of 18
points. New York University retained its title by scoring 602
points, with Haverford second with
41 points and Swarthmore third
with 25 points.
Gwinn Runs Mile

1

Hopkins was not able to garner
any first places, but was a close
second in three events—the mile and
two-mile runs and the broad jump.
In the one-mile run Gwinn was
picked to win by all of the experts,
but his chief opponent was declared
to be McMillan, of Union College.
The race started off at a good pace,
and after the first two laps Gwinn,
McMillan, and Getz, from Alfred
College, were bunched in the van.
At the beginning of the final lap
Alfred's entry began to sprint and
opened up a great lead on the other
two. Midway down the backstretch
Gwinn opened up and easily passed
McMillan, but he had allowed Getz
to get too much of a lead on him and
never was able to overhaul the fleet
New York runner. The last twenty
yards of the race were stirring, with
Gwinn coming on like an express
train and the yellow-jerseyed runner
in the lead just able to finish the
race, and establish a new Middle
States record for the mile of 4
minutes 2375 seconds, lowering the
old mark by 33
/
5 seconds.
New Record in Two-Mile Run

The second great distance performance of the day was turned in
by Schiebel, of the Jays, in the twomile. After the first two laps were
over, there were two distinctly different groups of runners. In the
lead was Totten of Union College,
Shirk of Dickinson, and Schiebel of
Hopkins.
This trio thundered
through the race, almost lapping the
remainder of the field. Just before
the beginning of the last lap, Totten
and Schiebel began to sprint, leaving
little Shirk far in the rear. Coming
around the last turn, the Union runner was able to gain a few yards and
he held this advantage through to
the finish, with Schiebel unable to
quite pick up the distance. Both
ran within the record time and
established a new mark of 9 minutes
4075 seconds. From out of nowhere Gwinn appeared and passed
Shirk in the last few strides for a
third place.
Other Points Scored

\riven garnered second place in
the broad jump, a wonderful showing considering the twisted muscles
in his legs. Berger's fourth in the
discus and W. Scheidt's fifth place
in the pole vault completed the scoring for the Jays.
This was the sixteenth annual
meet for the Middle States Champioaships and probably the fastest
one, six out of fourteen records
being equaled or broken.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 22, 1928

STRADER TO HEAD
VARSITY CLUB IN'29
Don.Stroder has been elected President of the Varsity
Club for next year, according
to a recent announcement.
Herman Scheibel was selected
for vice-presidency. The election is an annual occurrence
and was held last Thursday.
The meeting was the last one
of the year.
At the meeting, also, arrangements were made to
make elaborate preparations
for next year's entertainment
of out-of-town athletic teams.
Plans were made to more elaboratelv entertain high school
students who are prospective
athletes.

Last year just about this time a scrappy Scarlet lacrosse twelve gave
the stick world the biggest surprise of the season when it took a toosure Syracuse twelve into camp and ruined the latters' hope for intercollegiate stick laurels. Only last Wednesday the game New Brunswick stickmen handed lacrosse fans in general and Army in particular
the most upsetting jolt of the present season when Harry Wilson and
his teammates bowed to the Rutgers Scarlet by a 8-to-3 defeat.
. * * * * *
With the defeat of Army by Rutgers, only two of the many Olympic
contenders remain undefeated—Maryland and Mt. Washington. The
Olympic Committee, however, has assured stick fans that nothing has
been definitely decided, and nothing will be until the season is finished.
Should Hopkins defeat Maryland Saturday, Mt. Washington would
remain the only undefeated team in the country. But the Hillmen have
not played what are conceded to be three of the strongest teams in the
running—Army, Navy and Maryland. Their outstanding victory over
an Olympic contender, and almost their only one, is their victory over
Syracuse.
• * * * *
The much-defeated Harvard twelve was certainly made to feel the
results of the Army defeat Wednesday. Journeying to West Point
last Saturday, Wilson and Draper gave the Crimson twelve almost as
warm a reception as any received on the ill-fated Southern tour of the
Harvard stickmen when Doug. Turnbull and Fenny Baker went on
their scoring jag to chalk up a record score for the benefit of any
Olympic judges who might be present.
* * * * *
Mt. Washington this year is conceded to be the strongest twelve in
the country, and unless some quite unforeseen upset like the Army
defeat occurs, the Hillmen are almost sure of journeying to Amsterdam.
On May 30 the Mt. 'Washington stickmen will meet the toughtest team
on the schedule—the L'Hirondelle twelve—and anything might happen.
Both the Swallows and the Hillmen,,will go into the scrap with everything they've got. And they both have quite a lot.
* * * * *
The Swallows didn't give promise of much of a team at the beginning
of the season. They dropped their first two games—one to Maryland
at the end of March and their second to the fighting Johnnies at the
beginning of April. But since then their stock has gone up considerably, especially after the decisive 9-to-5 victory over the Crescents.
Any Mt. Washington-L'Hirondelle game, however, will furnish all the
fight and thrills of a EIopkins-Maryland scrap, no matter what the
caliber of the teams.

Never Gets
a "Bite" From
This Tobacco
Jasper, Tenn.
March 23, 1927
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
I have always wanted to smoke a
pipe. After several attempts I gave
my "taste" up, for with each trial I
got a blistered tongue.
One evening, when looking over a
certain outdoor magazine, I read that
a certain fisherman could catch more
fish when using "Edgeworth," so I
decided I would try "his" tobacco—
for I am no poor fisherman!
The next day I tried to secure Edgeworth. The local country storekeeper
did not have it, so I sent by a friend to
the city for my first Edgeworth. Two
things have happened: I still smoke
Edgeworth, and the local storekeeper
always has a supply.
I catch fish and never get "a bite"
from Edgeworth!
Yours for keeps,
H. V. Massey

Recalling his own college days as
being rather prankish and happygo-lucky, Dean Clark, of the University of Illinois, whom we picture
as a very exceptional and an unusually truthful faculty member, has
sufficient courage in his convictions
to state that "students of today
stand out as the most capable and
broadminded group of scholars in
the history of the country. Furthermore, modern colleges and universities are realizing a greater and
finer thing in college education than
they have ever approached before."
Unusually enough Dean Clark further ascribes one cause of the improved and more mature student as
being due to college activities which
as he says "have brought about a
radical change in the importance of
a college education."

THE JOHN HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 22, 1928

4

HALL HEARINGS
If statistics were taken to ascertain the number of students who always increase the size of their vacations, it is probable that the number
would be considerable. This was
the case in the Hall immediately
after the Easter furlough. Hardly
half the residents were present in
the dining room until the Monday
following vacation. The graduate
students, especially, enjoyed this, as
the usual amount of shoving and
pushing to get to the table first was
lacking.
*

*

*

The Scorpion Club of B entry has
been rather inactive of late. This is
an organization consisting of certain
members of B entry and an honorary member from F who was elected
to the club for his valuable and enlightening speeches on members of
the opposite sex. The club was in
the habit of meeting semi-monthly
(or any other time). The original
purpose of the club was to hold full
sessions weekly but when MacK. began to impart his information, the
meetings were in the form of lectures. Probably when he has exhausted his vast store of knowledge
on the subject, the club will revert
to the old system.
*

*

*

*

*

Each noon, crowds of students
can be seen in the Hall office reserving rooms for next year. They certainly are an optimistic lot.
*

*

*

The entry "B" boys have lost
their reputation of being a rough,
noisy and thoroughly disreputable
entry to the boys of "C" entry. The
entry "C" boys have been working
hard for this reputation for the past
several months and deserve it. At
last they have won it from "B,"
their rival entry for this distinction.
A recent party in "C" was the deciding factor. The entry "B" boys
themselves agreed that this party.
was equivalent to two of their best
parties. For three years "B" entry
was avoided by graduate students.
However, two graduate students
moved from "C" this year and one
last year.

lindfolded ... in scientific test of
leading Cigarettes, Princess Paul Chavchavadze

selects

OLD GOLD

"I was much intrigued by the invitation to make
a blindfold test of your leading brands of American cigarettes, to see how they compared with
each other and with those I had smoked abroad.
Could one really taste the difference? I wondered.
"But when I was handed these cigarettes, one by
one, I realized at once that there was a difference
and that the test was conclusive. One cigarette
was so much more appealing, so much more
delicate in flavor. Oh, and so much smoother!
"When the test was over and I was told that the
cigarette of my choice was OLD GOLD I understood
at once why this cigarette is so popular among
my American friends."

To calculate the number of tons
of mud tracked into the rooms of
Alumni Memorial Hall during the
rainfall last Friday would be an interesting problem for a graduate
student interested in transportation
methods in distribution of matter.
Friday the courtyard was entirely
submerged.

Joe Dorm attended a work-out of
the Alumni Memorial Hall Boxing
Organization, which exists for the
purpose of promoting the manly art
of self-defense. Joe suffered a set
of sore muscles after a severe battle
with his shadow.

On the Sunday morning of banquet season, at about 2 A. M., thirty
freshmen came to the Hall in quest
of a certain sophomore. They
knocked on his door and he failed
to reply. Unfortunately for him he
lived on the first floor. The frosh
then went to the back of the Hall
and, on finding the window locked,
broke one of them and walked in.
Where they got in they discovered
that his roommate, another soph,
had locked himself in the closet.
They immediately proceeded to take
down the closet door and haul out
the poor frightened little sophomore.
In getting out of the room they
pushed four panels out of two doors
and pulled the knobs off said portals.
Needless to say the room was quite
a wreck.

THE JOHN HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 22, 1928

Hullabaloo To Make
Appearance June 6
"The printing of the Hullabaloo
was started today and is expected
to be completed by June 6," Leonard Dalsemer, business manager,
announced last Friday. This is the
usual time for the publication of the
year book. Notices will be sent to
all students when the Hullabaloo
arrives and those who are out of
town at the time will receive their
year books next fall. This issue is
about 460 pages in length. The
color scheme has been changed from
the usual black.
INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
(Continued From Page 3, Column 1)

An ugly men's contest which is at
present underway at the University
of Cincinnati appears to be the latest in collegiate eccentricities, fads,
foibles, or what not. This novelty,
it is reported, has been adopted in
opposition to "nauseating" beauty
contests which are becoming increasingly popular even in college
today. Six candidates are entered
to date. Campaign speeches will be
made and after the voting "the ugliest man in the university" will be
given a silver loving cup at-the Annual Boat Ride.

BRITISH STUDENTS WILL STUDY AT
UNIVERSITY AS COMMONWEALTH FELLOWS
Hugh Graham Soulsby and
George E. Taylor, students of English universities, will come to Johns
Hopkins this year as holders of
Commonwealth fund fellowships,
according to a recent announcement.
Soulsby is a graduate of Durham
University, while Taylor is a student at Birmingham University.
The Durham graduate will study
Anglo-American relations in the
nineteenth century with reference to
the freedom of the seas and rights
of neutral powers in time of war.
Taylor will study the expansion of
the United States from the SpanishAmerican War to the World War.

The fellowships were established
in 1925 by the Commonwealth fund
of New York. They are awarded
annually and give the selected graduates of British and Colonial universities two years of study in
American universities and a summer
of travel in this country.

"The reaction of the undergraduate student body to the newly proposed cage has been favorable,"
said Dr. Ray Van Orman. The
demonstration during Thursday's
assembly at which "Father Bill"
Schmeisser explained the project
and urged support has been very encouraging. By last Friday approximately three thousand dollars had

Waldo Hambleton will take over
the coaching of the Hopkins track
and field team. He has been working with Ridgely Edwards throughout the past year to give him experience and get him acquainted with
Hopkins methods and men. He assisted Edwards not because a larger
staff is needed but. because of the
experience. He alone will coach the
team next year. Hambleton is an
old Hopkins man himself. He was
a weight man in his undergraduate
days, was on the swimming team,
and took part in the Musical Club.
Hambleton is now teaching over at
Poly.
Edwards To Leave

Ridgely Edwards is going to
Louisiana State University where
he wlil be assistant professor in
chemistry. It is not known whether
he will coach there or not. Edwards
leaves Hopkins with an enviable
record as a coach. "He has been
the best track coach since I have
been here," said Van Orman. "He
has always had the support of his
men. He has accomplished more

yet resisted. You will swim

the delightful deck games
that youth-on-a-lark devises.
And there'll be bridge,—
and conversation; — and
sometimes lost sleep! But
of course you have your
choice between missing
sleep and fun.
